Charlie was a magnetic leader, a loving father, and husband, and a friend and inspiration to so many. His loss is devastating, and I’ll always cherish the friendship I had with him. Charlie loved our nation and its founding principles and believed deeply in his faith, in his family, and in beauty of ideas and discussion. He lived with purpose and conviction, never shying away from hard truths and hard conversations, and always believing that the strength of our ideas and our faith could bring people together. Charlie worked to make our nation a better place in his 31 years before he was lost in an evil act of political violence, and will leave a lasting legacy on our nation. We know what Charlie would want us to do: he’d want us to stand strong by the ideas we believe in, have discussions, carry on with hope, strength, and courage, and look to God for guidance. I am proud to lead a resolution with @JimmyPatronis honoring Charlie’s legacy as an American patriot by designating October 14th, what would have been his 32nd birthday, as National Day of Remembrance for Charlie Kirk – a day to come together, pray, and celebrate Charlie’s impact on the nation.

I’m so proud to have another six years doing the best job in the world – serving the people of Florida as their U.S. Senator and fighting to protect the American dream for all Americans. 

When I became Governor of Florida in 2010, Florida’s economy was in shambles, I was determined to turn the state around and make sure that every family in Florida could get a great job, live in a safe community, and send their kids to a great school. I grew up in a family that struggled to make ends meet and I know firsthand that if you can build safe communities where businesses thrive and create jobs and kids can get a great education, everyone has a shot to live their American Dream. Florida’s turnaround playbook worked. That’s why I’ve spent my time as United States Senator working to bring Florida’s success to the federal government and making Washington Work for families. 

We’ve had so many great wins for Floridians over these past six years, and I’ll be spending every day of my second term as your U.S. Senator building on those efforts. 🚨 NEWS: I’m incredibly proud to continue serving the great state of Florida in the 119th Congress and be a new member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations and the Chairman of the U.S. Senate Special Committee on Aging. I’ll also continue serving on the U.S. Senate Committee on Armed Services, the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and the Committee on the Budget.

As a new member of the Committee on Foreign Relations, Chairman of the Special Committee on Aging, and member of the Armed Services, Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, and Budget committees, I will have the opportunity to fight every day in Washington for the issues most important to Florida families. During my time as Governor of Florida and U.S. Senator, I’ve made it a priority to put Florida families first and stand with our allies around the globe who believe in our way of life and freedoms. Hoy, me uní al Presidente Joe Biden y a la Administradora de @FEMAespanol, Deanne Criswell, en St. Pete Beach, que fue completamente destruida por el huracán Milton. Como dije después del huracán Helene, si bien agradezco que el presidente y la administradora de FEMA hayan venido a Florida para ver la devastación de primera mano, los floridanos todavía están sufriendo por las tormentas de hace años y el gobierno federal debe estar presente no solo hoy, sino todos los días. La marejada ciclónica no solo causó problemas mayors en la costa, sino que los primeros auxilios siguen realizando misiones de rescate mientras los ríos estan causando inundaciones y tornados destrozan comunidades enteras. Esta tormenta, junto con el huracán Helene, ha derribado a tantas comunidades, pero los floridanos son resilientes. Después del huracán Helene, le dije al Presidente Biden exactamente lo que se necesita para garantizar que Florida tenga todos los recursos federales para recuperarse por completo de esa tormenta y ahora del huracán Milton, lo reiteré en nuestra llamada de la semana pasada y nuevamente hoy. El presidente me dijo que estaba de acuerdo conmigo en esto la semana pasada. También debemos asegurarnos de que FEMA abra Centros de Recuperación de Desastres cerca de las áreas más afectadas, para que los afectados tengan fácil acceso a los recursos federales para recuperarse. Finalmente, volví a enfatizar al Presidente Biden la importancia de que el USDA apruebe de inmediato subvenciones en bloque para nuestros agricultores que han estado luchando desde Ian en 2022. Hablé de las mismas cosas durante mis llamadas del jueves con la Administradora de FEMA Deanne Criswell y la Administradora de SBA Isabel Casillas Guzman. Today, I joined President Joe Biden and FEMA Administrator Deanne Criswell on the ground in St. Pete Beach, which was completely destroyed by Hurricane Milton. Like I said following Hurricane Helene, while I appreciate the president and FEMA Administrator coming to Florida to see the devastation firsthand, Floridians are still hurting from storms years ago, and the federal government needs to show up not just today but every day. Not only did storm surge cause significant issues on the coast, but first responders are still conducting non-stop rescue missions as rising rivers cause inland flooding and tornadoes ripped apart entire communities. This storm, along with Hurricane #Helene, has knocked so many communities down, but Floridians are resilient. Following Hurricane Helene, I told President Biden exactly what is needed to ensure Florida has every federal resource to fully recover from that storm and now Hurricane #Milton, I reiterated that in our call last week and again today. Here’s what I stressed to the President: I’m calling on Schumer to bring the Senate back ASAP when our communities have assessed their needs, which I told the president must be expedited, to pass needed disaster funding for FEMA, @SBAgov and the USDA and approve common sense relief like my Federal Disaster Tax Relief Act. The president told me he agreed with me on this last week. We must also ensure FEMA opens Disaster Recovery Centers close to the areas hit hardest, so those impacted have easy access to federal resources to recover. Finally, I again stressed to @POTUS the importance of @USDA immediately approving block grants for our farmers that have been struggling since Ian in 2022. I discussed the same things during my calls on Thursday with @FEMA Administrator @FEMA_Deanne Criswell and SBA Administrator @SBAIsabel Casillas Guzman. I’m going to continue fighting like hell to make sure this happens and aid is delivered to families in need.

Si bien agradezco al Presidente Biden, al secretario del USDA, Tom Vilsack, y a los funcionarios de FEMA por haber venido a Florida para ver los daños aquí de primera mano, hay mucho trabajo por hacer. Durante mi reunión con el Presidente Biden, subrayé que la respuesta del gobierno federal a los huracanes durante los últimos dos años ha dejado a demasiados floridanos, especialmente a nuestros agricultores, sufriendo y con necesidades insatisfechas, y esto debe solucionarse AHORA. Se necesitarán esfuerzos locales, estatales y federales para ayudar a las comunidades a recuperarse a lo largo de la Costa del Golfo. Por eso he exigido que el líder de la mayoría Chuck Schumer vuelva a convocar de inmediato al Senado una vez que FEMA y SBA finalicen las evaluaciones de daños para que podamos financiar por completo a estas agencias, al USDA y a otras que responden a este desastre con un proyecto de ley de asignaciones suplementarias para desastres. Lucharé para entregar ayuda a nuestro estado y garantizar una guía de remoción de escombros para nuestras comunidades locales, e insté a los funcionarios federales hoy a que pongan a los floridanos y a todos los estadounidenses de primero. Desde el huracán Ian, Washington ha jugado con los fondos de ayuda para desastres y ha retrasado la entrega de la asistencia urgentemente necesaria de FEMA y otras ayudas como las subvenciones en bloque del USDA para los agricultores de Florida y mi Proyecto de ley Federal Disaster Tax Relief Act. Esta ayuda se ha proporcionado a las víctimas de huracanes en el pasado, pero ese no ha sido el caso desde los huracanes Ian, Debby e Idalia y eso debe cambiar para que podamos entregar esta ayuda AHORA.

“El huracán Helene devastó comunidades a lo largo de cientos de millas de la Costa del Golfo de Florida y causó daños y pérdidas inimaginables en el condado de Taylor y en todo el Big Bend. Desde los días previos a la tormenta, he visitado comunidades afectadas en 11 condados para reunirme con funcionarios locales y estatales y escuchar lo que necesitan del gobierno federal, y he estado en contacto constante con funcionarios estatales y federales para coordinar recursos. Los floridanos son resilientes, pero la recuperación no recae solo en estas familias: es una operación que requiere que el gobierno federal esté presente hoy, mañana y todos los días hasta que el trabajo esté hecho y no dejaré de luchar para asegurarme de que eso suceda.

While I appreciate President Biden, USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack and officials from FEMA coming to Florida to see the damage here firsthand, there is so much work to be done. During my meeting with President Biden, I stressed that the federal government’s response to hurricanes over the last two years has left too many Floridians, especially our farmers, hurting and with unmet needs – and this must be fixed NOW. It is going to take local, state and federal efforts to help communities recover along the Gulf Coast. That’s why I’ve demanded that Majority Leader Chuck Schumer immediately reconvene the Senate once FEMA and the SBA finalize damage assessments so we can fully fund these agencies, the USDA, and others responding to this disaster with a clean disaster supplemental appropriations bill. I’ll be fighting like hell to deliver disaster aid to our state, and ensure seamless debris removal guidance for our local communities, and I urged the federal officials there today to put Floridians and all Americans first by doing the same. Since Hurricane Ian, Washington has played games with disaster relief funds and delayed the delivery of urgently needed FEMA assistance, and other aid like USDA block grants for Florida’s farmers and my Federal Disaster Tax Relief Act. This aid has been routinely provided to victims of hurricanes in the past but that has not been the case since Hurricanes Ian, Debby and Idalia and that must change so we can deliver this aid NOW.

Hurricane Helene devastated communities along hundreds of miles of Florida’s Gulf Coast and caused unimaginable damage and loss in Taylor County and across the Big Bend. Since the days before the storm, I’ve visited impacted communities in 11 counties to meet with local and state officials and hear what they need from the federal government, and been in constant contact with state and federal officials to coordinate resources. Floridians are resilient, but recovery doesn’t fall just on these families – it’s an all hands on deck operation that requires the federal government to show up today, tomorrow and every day until the job is done and I won’t stop fighting to make sure that happens.

Since Category 4 Hurricane Helene made its devastating landfall in the Big Bend and caused massive and destructive storm surge along hundreds of miles of Florida’s Gulf Coast, I have been traveling to impacted communities to survey damage and coordinate resources between the local, state and federal governments. What I have seen, from the catastrophic damage in Cedar Key, to the massive destruction caused by unprecedented storm surge in communities from Fort Myers Beach to Siesta Key and Anna Maria Island and north to Pinellas, Pasco and Hernando counties is heartbreaking. News reports of the devastation in Georgia, North Carolina, Tennessee, and other communities impacted by Hurricane Helene are also devastating. Floridians are resilient, but the response and recovery from this storm demands the full and immediate support of government at every level to get families and businesses back to normal. While I know from my experience with previous hurricanes that @FEMA and @SBAgov damage assessments take time, I am today urging Majority Leader @SenSchumer to immediately reconvene the U.S. Senate when those assessments are completed so that we can pass the clean supplemental disaster funding bill and other disaster relief legislation, like my Federal Disaster Tax Relief Act, needed to ensure the full recovery of families in all impacted communities. While we wait for this critical information, I will keep fighting to make sure that FEMA, the SBA, and the entire federal government is working in total collaboration with state and local officials so we continue to get resources and aid deployed quickly.
